newsitem.title: DENMARK: SAS unworried by strike threat.
newsitem.headline: SAS unworried by strike threat.

text.p: Ground staff at Scandinavian Airlines System (SAS) are threatening to strike this week and next but airline management is unpeturbed, the Danish news agency Ritzau reported on Monday.
"No action has been taken as yet and we expect normal working, both this week and next," it quoted company spokesman Jens Peter Skaarup as saying.

The 1300-member LFF union, grouping check-in, ticket sales and other non-technical ground staff, issued a strike warning after its chairman was reprimanded by management for allegedly entering a training area without authorisation.

SAS suffered successive waves of strikes last year, increasing passenger dissatisfaction with punctuality and service. --Soeren Linding Jakobsen, Copenhagen newsroom +45 33969653 said on Monday that it planned to open a regional freight depot on western Denmark's Jutland peninsula next year.

An SAS statement said that the new centre would open in August 1997, to coincide with the opening of a road and rail bridge linking Jutland and continental Europe to the island of Zealand, where the capital, Copenhagen, is situated.
SAS freight would continue to enter and leave Denmark through Copenhagen airport and be fowarded by land to provincial destinations, but the new depot would speed delivery, SAS said.
The statement did not give the handling capacity of the new depot nor its cost. --Steve Weizman, Copenhagen newsroom +45 33969650
